review.title: Landmark-Based Plan Recognition
review.abstract: Recognition of goals and plans using incomplete evidence from action execution can be done efficiently by using planning techniques. In many applications it is important to recognize goals and plans not only accurately, but also quickly. In this paper, we develop a heuristic approach for recognizing plans based on planning techniques that rely on ordering constraints to filter candidate goals from observations. In the planning literature, these ordering constraints are called landmarks, which are facts or actions that cannot be avoided to achieve a goal. We show the applicability of planning landmarks in two settings: first, we use it directly to develop a heuristic-based plan recognition approach; second, we refine an existing planning-based plan recognition approach. Our empirical evaluation shows that our approach is not only substantially more accurate than the state-of-the-art in all available datasets, it is also an order of magnitude faster.
histories: Accepted as short paper in the 22nd European Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ECAI 2016

metadata.title: Landmark-Based Plan Recognition

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: As more computer systems require considerations about what agents (both human and artificial) do besides themselves, the ability to accurately and efficiently detect targets and plans from agents "behavior is becoming more and more important. Planning knowledge is the task of identifying goals and plans based on often incomplete observations that include actions carried out by agents and agents" behavior in an environment [18]. Precise planning knowledge is important to monitor and anticipate agents "behavior, such as in detecting and preventing crime, monitoring activities, and elderlycare. Most planning recognition approaches are executed by plan libraries (i.e., a library of all plans for achieving goals) to represent agents" behavior, leading to approaches analogous to language parsing. Recent work, 15, 13] uses planning domain definitions (i.e., a library of plans for achieving goals) to approach planning algorithms to represent potential behavior.

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: In this section, we provide basic background information on the terminology of planning and how we define planning recognition problems over definitions of planning areas.

sections.heading: 2.1 Planning
sections.text: In this work we adopt the terminology of Ghallab et al. [8] to describe planning domains and problems. Firstly, we define a condition in the environment by the following definition 1. sections.heading: 2.2 Plan Recognition
sections.text: Most plan recognition approaches require knowledge of an agent's possible plans to represent his typical behavior, in other words, this knowledge provides the recipes (i.e. the know-how) for achieving goals. These recipes are often referred to as plan libraries and serve as input for many plan recognition approaches [7, 1]. In this work, however, we use as input a definition of the planning area, or more precisely, the STRIPS [6] fragment of the PDDL [12]. We follow Ramırez and Geffner [16, 15] to formally define a plan recognition problem via a definition of the planning area as the following. Definition 7 (Plan Recognition Problem) is the definition of a plan recognition problem for the execution of such a sequence. A plan recognition problem is a quadruple TPR = < I, G, O >, in which a plan recognition problem via a definition of the planning area Plan Recognition Problem can be defined as the following action definition (Recognition 7 is complete).

sections.heading: 3 Extracting Recognition Information from Planning Definition
sections.text: In this section, we describe the process by which we extract useful information for planning recognition from a planning area. First, we describe ground-breaking extraction algorithms from literature and how we use these algorithms in our approach. Second, we show how we divide facts from planning descriptions into partitions.

sections.heading: 3.1 Extracting Landmarks
sections.text: In the planning literature, landmarks [9] are defined as necessary features that must be aligned at some point in any valid plan in order to achieve a certain goal. Landmarks are often partially ordered according to the order in which they must be achieved. Hoffman et al. [9] define landmarks as follows. Definition 8 (Landmark): In the face of a planning instance, a landmark is a kind of formula (e.g. subjunctive formula or subjunctive formula) over a set of facts that at some point along all valid plan implementations.For plan recognition problems, landmarks can be inferred from whether a sequence of observations cannot possibly lead to a specific goal (e.g. subjunctive formula or subjunctive formula) or subjunctive formula over a set of facts along all valid plan implementations.For plan recognition problems, we can infer a sequence of observation marks that cannot possibly lead to a specific goal. To extract the landmarks of a planning problem, we use two landmarks extract algorithms from the literature: 1).

sections.heading: 5 Heuristic Plan Recognition using Landmarks
sections.text: We are now developing a trend-setting heuristic method that estimates the goal of achieving each goal in the series of filtered goals by analyzing the number of goals achieved for each goal achieved through the filtering process. (Each candidate, however, is composed of partial goals: partial goals that are part of a linkage of facts. (Our heuristic method estimates the percentage of goals achieved toward a goal by measuring the percentage of partial goals achieved (atomic facts that are part of a conjunction of facts) in a goal that was achieved based on the evidence of the facts achieved in the observations.Our heuristic method estimates the percentage of goals achieved toward a goal by measuring the partial goals provided by the filtering process (algorithm 1, line 15).We aggregate the percentage of achievement of each partial goal into an aggregate percentage of achievement for all facts in a candidate goal. This heuristic method, called hprl, calculates the goals achieved by the following formula, where we achieve the partial number of the goals.

sections.heading: 6 Landmark-based Plan Recognition
sections.text: We now summarize the techniques from Sections 4 and 5 in our groundbreaking Plan Recognition Approach, which uses the presented filter and heuristics to identify goals and plans. Our Plan Recognition Approach is described in detail in Algorithm 2. This algorithm takes a plan recognition problem as input and operates in two stages. In the first stage, this algorithm filters the candidate goals using the filter (Algorithm 1), which returns goals to the candidate with the highest percentage of milestones achieved within a given threshold. In the second stage, this algorithm recognizes goals and plans using the filter method and ground-breaking Heuristics (Eq.1) to return the recognized goals by estimating the percentage of completion achieved based on the milestones provided by the filter. Algorithm 2 recognizes goals and plans based on the filter method and ground-breaking Heuristics. Input: High Quality Heuristics (Equation 1), calculating the percentage of completion achieved by the filter based on the milestones achieved.

sections.heading: 7 Experiments and Evaluation
sections.text: In this section, we describe the experiments and evaluation we have carried out on our ground-breaking based plan-recognition approach. • For experiments, we use six domains from datasets provided by Ramı ́ rez and Geffner. [16, 15] which include hundreds of problems6. We summarize these domains as follows. • BLOCKS-WORLD domain consists of a series of blocks, a table and a robot hand. Blocks can be stacked on top of other blocks or on the table. A block that has nothing on it is clear. • The robot can hold a block or be empty. The goal is to find a sequence of actions that will achieve a final configuration of blocks; • CAMPUS domain consists of finding what activity is being carried out by a student from his / her observations on campus; • EASY-IPC-GRID domain consists of an agent moving in a network of cells to another by transporting keys to open places.
It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.
It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.
It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

In the BLOCKS-WORLD domain, the accuracy of metric measures is how well these approaches are detected from observations, the word that is put together. In the CAMPUS domain, we aim to accurately detect how well these activities are performed by an observed student. In the EASY-IPC-GRID domain, how exactly these approaches detect the cell in which keys are transported by the observed agent.

sections.heading: 8 Related Work
sections.text: Ramı ́ rez and Geffner [16] propose planning approaches for recognizing plans, and instead of using plan libraries, they model the problem as a planning domain theory relative to a known set of objectives. Their work uses a heuristic, optimal, and modified suboptimal planner to determine the distance to each goal in a series of objectives after observation. Succession work [15] suggests a probabilistic plan recognition approach using standard planners. However, in most areas, these approaches provide a high level of accuracy that is lower than our threshold-based approaches, and their detection time ranges from twice slower to an order of magnitude slower. Pattison and Long [13] suggest IGRAPH (AUTOmatic Goal Recognition with A Planning Heuristic), a probable heuristic target recognition across planning domains. IGRAPH uses heuristic estimation and domain analysis to determine what objectives a planning problem is pursuing.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: We have developed an approach to plan recognition based on planning landmarks and a new heuristics based on these landmarks. Landmarks provide key information about what cannot be avoided to achieve a goal, and we show that landmarks can be efficiently used for highly accurate plan recognition. We have shown empirically that our approach not only delivers superior accuracy results, but also significantly faster detection times for all areas used in state-of-the-art assessment [16], with varying degrees of observation completeness. Our experiments show that disjunctive landmarks in at least one domain have a positive effect on accuracy with minimal impact on detection time, while in some domains these landmarks are either non-existent or produce almost no gain in accuracy at significant speed loss. Knowledge of the domains leads us to believe that disjunctive landmarks are most useful in domains where we assume that domains observed are only suboptimal, such as the CHEN plans.

We compare our approach to two other approaches: the approach of Ramı́rez and Geffner [16], more specifically, we use their faster and most accurate approach; as well as a combination of their approach and our filter.

From this table, it is possible to see that our landmark-based plan recognition approach is both faster and more accurate than Ramı́rez and Geffner [16], and, when we combine their algorithm with our filter, the resulting approach gets a substantial speedup.

[5] propose a planning-based plan recognition approach that propagates cost and interaction information in a plan graph, and uses this information to estimate goal probabilities over the set of candidate goals.

We have shown empirically that our approach yields not only superior accuracy results but also substantially faster recognition times for all domains used in evaluating against the state of the art [16] at varying observation completeness levels.
First, we aim to evaluate other planning techniques, such as heuristics and symmetries in classical planning [17].
Second, we intend to explore other landmark extraction algorithms to obtain additional information from planning domains, such as temporal landmarks [10].

metadata.abstractText: Recognition of goals and plans using incomplete evidence from action execution can be done efficiently by using planning techniques. In many applications it is important to recognize goals and plans not only accurately, but also quickly. In this paper, we develop a heuristic approach for recognizing plans based on planning techniques that rely on ordering constraints to filter candidate goals from observations. These ordering constraints are called landmarks in the planning literature, which are facts or actions that cannot be avoided to achieve a goal. We show the applicability of planning landmarks in two settings: first, we use it directly to develop a heuristic-based plan recognition approach; second, we refine an existing planning-based plan recognition approach by pre-filtering its candidate goals. Our empirical evaluation shows that our approach is not only substantially more accurate than the state-of-the-art in all available datasets, it is also an order of magnitude faster.
